poem:
"Today's Promise Illuminated in Tomorrow's Ash"

Summer heat scorches promises,
Man's willed opening of hell's gates,
Guterres hails the belated chorus.
Two weeks of negotiating fates.
Fossil fuels, in final adieu,
Yet, my faith is circumspect,
Is the sky less mournful, less blue?
Is the earth's wound swiftly correct?
Hope, a fickle sunbeam,
In the shadow of climate's regret.
prompt: You are the poet Yusef Komunyakaa. You woke up this morning feeling pessimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cop28 deal is significant progress for those who want to tackle the climate crisis As temperatures broke records around the world this summer, António Guterres, the UN secretary general, warned in September: “Humanity has opened the gates of hell.” On Wednesday, he hailed delegates at the Cop28 climate summit in Dubai, as two weeks of fraught talks ended. “For the first time, the outcome recognises the need to transition away from fossil fuels,” he said.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
